If you have raw fitness (rf) being the RMSE, then you  can
let the actual fitness (f) be...


f=1/(1+rf)


... which will give you values of fitness in (0,1) with 0 being
the worst and 1 being the best.

Stephen Waits wrote:
>
>
> On Oct 9, 2007, at 6:55 PM, psyphiroth.nebu wrote:
>
>> Thanks very much for your advice, but if I use root mean square
>> error, doesn't that mean the best individual gets the lowest fitness
>> value?
>
> Yes, see below.
>
>> Since I am new to the ANN world, some things rather confuse me. I am
>> now using MATLAB_NEAT to do some work by modifying the
>> XOR_EXPERIMENT, but I found that the node output will always be
>> positive in the program, then how can I emulate a curve with negetive
>> values?
>
> For that you'll need to change the activation function to something 
> that goes from say [-1,1].  You could transform a [0,1] activation 
> function to this by 2*(x-0.5).
>
>> Ken told me I should always try to get better individuals higher
>> fitness values, but when I employ the method that XOR_EXPERIMENT
>> uses, I found it is difficult to locate a proper constant from which
>> the error is substracted for random output patern. Is there any rules
>> to determine the constant?
>
> IIRC, fitness needs to be positive in NEAT for fitness sharing (and 
> hence, speciation) to work right.
>
> Yes, you'll need to come up with a constant that works.  That depends 
> on your problem - but shouldn't be too difficult to determine.  Note 
> that you should be subtracting the RMSE though, not the Error.  So, 
> run all of your fitness evaluations, computing RMSE, then subtract 
> each RMSE from some constant.
>
> I've never used Ken's or Matlab NEAT though, so I cannot speak to the 
> specifics of each.  So what I'm telling you may or not make sense in 
> your environment.
>
> Don't hesitate to keep asking questions though.  There are lots of 
> kind and helpful people on this mailing list.  I'm sure we'll get you 
> up and running.
> --
> Stephen Waits
> steve@... <mailto:steve@...>
> http://swaits.com <http://swaits.com>/
>
>
>
